process_s.name: Sleep Homeostasis (Sleep Pressure)
process_s.description: Builds up the longer you're awake
process_s.mechanism: Adenosine accumulates in the brain during waking hours
process_s.duration: Increases over ~16 hours awake, decreases during ~8 hours sleep
process_s.function: Creates sleep pressure/drive - makes you feel sleepy

process_c.name: Circadian Rhythm (Body Clock)
process_c.mechanism: Controlled by suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) in brain, regulated by light
process_c.function: Regulates when you feel alert vs. sleepy throughout the day

adenosine.how_it_works: Accumulates during wakefulness, increases sleep drive

melatonin.how_it_works: Produced when it gets dark, signals body it's time to sleep

cortisol.pattern: High in morning, decreases throughout day

n2.name: Stage 2 (Light Sleep)
n2.characteristics: Heart rate slows, body temperature drops

n3.name: Stage 3 (Deep Sleep)
n3.characteristics: Most restorative, tissue repair, immune system boost

tips: Go to bed and wake up at the same time daily (even weekends)
Aim for 10-11 PM bedtime (aligned with natural melatonin rise)
Get bright light in first 30-60 min after waking (advances circadian rhythm)
Avoid bright/blue light 1-2 hours before bed (delays rhythm)
Morning light advances sleep phase, evening light delays it
Exercise during day (not close to bedtime)
Create relaxing pre-sleep routine (reading, bath, meditation)
Long/late naps reduce nighttime sleep pressure

how_processes_work_together.optimal_sleep_timing: When Process S (high sleep pressure after 16 hrs awake) meets Process C (circadian low point around 10 PM-7 AM)
how_processes_work_together.morning: Process S is low (just slept), Process C promotes wakefulness
how_processes_work_together.midday: Process S building, Process C still promoting alertness
how_processes_work_together.evening: Process S high, Process C begins promoting sleep
how_processes_work_together.night: Both processes aligned to promote deep, consolidated sleep

what_disrupts_sleep: Light at night (suppresses melatonin, delays sleep phase)
Napping too long or too late
